Name: None
Description: No leader

Name: William the Bastard
Description: William the Bastard, William the Duke of Normandy, William the Conqueror, was the first Norman to rule over England after wrestling the control from the Anglo-Saxon king, Harold Godwinson, in the invasion of England in 1066. From the still young House of Normandy, which ruled over the Normandy region since 911, William was one of the prime contenders whom King Edward the Confessor appoint as his heir. The throne of England is always in his destiny and nothing will stop his rightful conquest.

Name: Alan the Red
Description: Alan Rufus or "the Red (beard)" was a Breton nobleman and close companion of William the Conqueror. As part of the Invasion of England, he is the commander of the Breton force in William's army. After the successful invasion, Alan was granted amass fortune and the title Earl of Richemont and remain an important figure in William's court and ruling achievement, which later on allows him to become one of the wealthiest individuals in Europe

Name: William FitzOsbern
Description: William fitzOsbern was a cousin and close companion of William the Conqueror. He was a nobleman who rules over Breteuil, Normandy before becoming Earl of Hereford and Essex after Norman conquest. After the invasion, he remained one of the most important political figures in Norman England, while his name became and is still renown for many castles that he commissioned. He met his end in the Battle of Cassel while persuing the wealth of Flanders principality.

Name: Eustace II
Description: Eustace II was a Count of Boulogne who fought in the Battle of Hastings. He was one of the commanders that lead the charge of Norman Knights and was struck by a battle-axe from Saxon Huscarl in the battle. After the invasion, Eustace rebelled against William the Conqueror due to the dissatisfaction of war spoil and possibly for a claim on the English throne. The rebellion ultimately failed but William and Eustace reconciled with Eustace retained some of his holdings and remained in William's court.

Name: William d'Evreux
Description: William d'Evreux was a Norman nobleman who fought alongside William the Conqueror in the Battle of Hastings and contributed to the construction of Norman fleet. Not much is known of his personal role in the battle, but after the invasion, William was granted multiple landholdings but no noteworthy nobility title from the war contribution. Later on in his life, William inherited Count of Evreux from his father and participate in many battles likes Battle of Tinchebray under King Henry I.

Name: Robert de Beaumont
Description: Robert de Beaumont was a Norman nobleman who fought in the Battle of Hastings on the side of William the Conqueror. It is believed that Robert fought with the French (Frank) troops on the right wing of the Norman army. He later became the County of Meulan after Count Hugh I, his uncle, died and Earl of Leicester during the reign of Henry I.

Name: Geoffrey II
Description: Geoffrey II was the Count of Mortagne and later Count of Perche who participated in Norman invasion and Battle of Hastings on William's side. After the invasion, he fought against Robert of Belleme, a prominent noble, in a land dispute but ultimately failed. Later on, he became renown for his spiritual pursuit and charitable acts such as establishing leper colonies, the place to keep leper isolated from society, in his region.

Name: Aimery IV of Thouars
Description: Aimery (or Aimeri) IV of Thouars was a Viscount who fought against William the Conqueror in the Siege of Ambrieres. During the Norman invasion, he joined the Norman force and commanded the Breton wing of the army during the Battle of Hastings. After the invasion, he returned to his holding in France and ruled there for another three decades until he was assassinated.

Name: Walter Giffard
Description: Walter Giffard was one of the closest companions of William the Conqueror who fought with him long before the Norman invasion. A veteran knight, landowner and later Baron of Long Crendon, Walter Giffard fought in the Reconquista against the Moors and contributed to the Norman invasion significantly and personally fought in the Battle of Hastings.

Name: Hugh de Montfort
Description: Hugh II de Montfort was a Norman nobleman from Montfort-sur-Risle who participated in the Battle of Hastings on the side of William the Conqueror. Hugh II was one of the major companions who fought alongside William long before the invasion and also participated Council of Lillebonne. Although his role in the Battle of Hastings is not evidently recorded, the numerous reward of holding from Domesday book evidence suggests that his contribution to the war and battle are likely to be significant.

Name: Raoul II of Tosny
Description: A Norman nobleman of House Tosny, Raoul II of Tosny who fought on the side of William the Conqueror in the Battle of Mortimer. Later he also participated in the Battle of Hastings possibly fighting nearby the Duke himself. After the invasion, he was rewarded greatly by the now King William with lands and war spoils. However, his life was in no shortage of conflicts. He fought against William d'Evreux and later on against Robert de Beaumont.

Name: Hugh de Grandmesnil
Description: Hugh de Grandmesnil was one of the noble companions of William the Conqueror that originally got banished by William from Normandy but managed to regain the Duke's Favour again years later. He joined the Duke in Norman conquest and personally fought in multiple battles. He was rewarded handsomely with multiple landholdings and was appointed the Sheriff of Leicestershire. He remained an important political figure during William's reign and joined in a conflict against Robert de Beaumont.

Name: William de Warenne
Description: William de Warenne was among Norman nobles that participate in Council of Lillebonne and Norman invasion. After the successful invasion, he received numerous landholdings as a reward but remained somewhat minor noble in Norman court. Only later, He became Earl of Surrey during the reign of William the Conqueror's third son, William II Rufus (The Red) for his loyalty to the king during the rebellion. He fought against the rebels and met his end during the Siege of Pevensey Castle.

Name: William Malet
Description: William Malet was a minor noble and a key officer in William the Conqueror's army during the Battle of Hastings. Although there is a record to support that he fought in the battle, it is not known of his exact role nor contribution in the invasion. Nevertheless, there is a record that the Duke gave Harold Godwinson's corpse to him for burial instead of accepting Harold's mother's gold offers and he was significantly rewarded with lands and wealth for his contribution to the invasion and became Sheriff of Yorkshire.

Name: Odo of Bayeux
Description: Another half-brother of William the Conqueror and older brother of Robert of Mortain. Odo of Bayeux was a cleric turned warrior and Earl of Kent renown for his contribution to the Norman invasion. He was also very likely the person who commissioned Bayeux Tapestry, an immensely important historical relic of propagandistic nature that chronicle the events leading up to the Battle of Hastings. Interestingly his life after the invasion was not a pleasant one. After multiple imprisonments and a failed rebellion, he died on his journey for the First Crusade in Sicily.

Name: Turstin FitzRolf
Description: Turstin FitzRolf is the name of a person who was a companion of William the Conqueror. With unknown role and accomplishment, it is more likely that he was a knight under William's service than a minor noble. After the invasion, he was granted multiple Baronies and holdings in Somerset.

Name: Geoffrey de Montbray
Description: Geoffrey de Montbray was a Bishop from a noble house and a political advisor for William the Conqueror likely both before and after the invasion. He fought in the Battle of Hastings and participated in multiple battles after against the subsequent rebellions. As a religious cleric, the chronicle remarks that Geoffrey was more skilled in the military matter than his official duty.

Name: Robert of Mortain
Description: Robert of Mortain was a Count of Mortain and William the Conqueror's another half-brother who is no doubt one of the closest companions of Duke William. His name is recorded as a participant in the war council and contributor to the invasion fleet. Not much is known for his role in the battle but after the invasion, Robert was rewarded a significant portion of war spoil and land for his contribution. He was also the leader of the failed revolt against William II over the succession dispute.

Name: Wadard
Description: Wadard is the name of the person that appear in Bayeux Tapestry and Domesday book who believed to be a nobleman of unknown origin. It was believed that he may be a noble from Bayeux or less possibly a residence near Hastings. Regardless of origin, it is crucial that his name appear in the Tapestry, which indicate his importance to William's court and likely fought in the Battle of Hastings.

Name: Vital
Description: Vital is the name of another person beside Wadard that appear in Bayeux Tapestry. It is believed that he was one of Odo of Bayeux's followers and tenants beside Wadard and the dwarf, Turold. He very likely fought in the Battle of Hastings but not much else is known about his origin, accomplishment and fate after the invasion.

Name: Gilbert d'Auffay
Description: Gilbert d'Auffay was one of Norman nobles who followed William the Conqueror to invade England and participated in the Battle of Hastings. After the invasion, he returned to his holding in Normandy and ruled there until his final rest.

Name: Humphrey I
Description: Humphrey "The Bearded" or "The Old" was a Norman noble who found the house of Bohon. He was also William the Conqueror's godfather and accompanied William in the invasion and participated in the Battle of Hastings. He was rewarded generously for his contribution in invasion and remained a major figure in William's ruling.

Name: Engenulf of Laigle
Description: Engenulf of Laigle or Engenulphe de Laigle was a Baron of Laigle who accompanied William the Conqueror in the invasion. He died shortly after the Battle of Hastings, possibly while chasing the fleeing Saxon soldiers.

Name: Richard fitz Gilbert
Description: Richard fitz Gilbert was a Norman noble and another half-brother of William the Conqueror. As Richard was an illegitimate son of Gilbert, Count of Brionne, he did not inherit the title when his father died. Richard accompanied William the Conqueror in the Invasion of England and was well rewarded with a vast amount of English lands including the lordship of Clare, in Suffolk. Richard was also part of the succession rebellion in 1088. He was punished severely after the failed rebellion.

Name: Harold Godwinson
Description: The Saxon king of England, Harold Godwinson is the rightful heir of Edward the Confessor (at least according to himself). Originally the Earl of East Anglia, Harold was already extremely influential person long before his kingship. His short reign of one year as the last Saxon king was nothing short of troubling, having to defend against both invasions from Norse and Norman in the same year. He and his two brothers were killed in the Battle of Hastings thus signal the new reign of Norman in Albion.

Name: Gyrth Godwinson
Description: Gyrth Godwinson was the younger brother of Harold Godwinson, King of England. Godwinson was one of the most powerful houses during the reign of Edward the Confessor, Gyrth himself hold multiple Earldom in East England along with his brothers. Along with his brothers, Gyrth commanded a significant portion of the Saxon army in the Battle of Hastings. It is believed that Gyrth is killed by William the Conqueror himself in personal combat as recorded in multiple sources.

Name: Leofwine Godwinson
Description: Leofwine Godwinson was the younger of Harold Godwinson and Earl of multiple regions in East England. Having followed Harold throughout his life, it is interesting to note that Leofwine and the other brother did not fight in the Battle of Stamford Bridge. Nevertheless, Leofwine along with his two brothers fought and perished in the Battle of Hastings.

Name: Godric of Berkshire
Description: Godric was a Saxon sheriff of Berkshire who fought in the Battle of Hastings on the side of Harold Godwinson's army. Not much is known about Godric beside his land ownership and title from the Domesday Book. But according to the chronicle of the monastery of Abingdon, he was part of a few named individuals killed during the battle.

Name: Thurkill
Description: Thurkill was one of the landowners or thanes who participated in the Battle of Hastings on Harold Godwinson's side. Most of the thanes were the leader of the Fyrd militias, while the noble led alongside the Huscarls. Thurkill, along with many other unnamed thanes and nobles, perished in the battle along with their kings. Thus, leaving a vast amount of land to be claimed as war spoil by William the Conqueror.

Name: Edric the Deacon
Description: Edric the Deacon was a landowner (thane) from Suffolk who joined Harold Godwinson in the Battle of Hastings and perished along with many others. Besides his ownership evident from Domesday book, which also indicates his death, not much else is known.

Name: Breme
Description: Another landowner (thane) from Suffolk who joined Harold Godwinson in the Battle of Hastings. Breme along with Thurkill and Edric the Deacon are one of many thanes who perished in the battle.

Name: Aelfwig of New Minster
Description: Aelfwig was an abbot (head of a monastery) of New Minster during the Invasion of England. He and twelve fellow monks joined Harold's force in the Battle of Hastings. Equipped with monk robe and chainmail, they are no doubt one of the literal warrior monks one often seen in a fictional story. Aelfwig was, unfortunately, one of the few named individuals that perished on Senlac Hill, likely along with his fellow monks.

Name: Aelfric
Description: Aelfric was a landowner (thane) from Huntingdonshire who participated in  Battle of Hastings on the side of Harold Godwinson. He perished along with many others that day.

Name: Son of Helloc
Description: An unnamed warrior who was recorded to fight on the side of Harold Godwinson in the Battle of Hastings. He was believed to be a Huscarl of Gyrth Godwinson who managed to kill William of Normandy horse in the battle with a javelin. He was then cut down by William himself who proceeded to rush into the Saxon rank with rage after two of his warhorses fell.

Name: Thutmose III
Description: Pharaoh Thutmose III of the New Kingdom was one of the greatest Pharoah in Ancient Egypt history. He expanded his empire into from Nubia to Syria in 20 successful military campaigns. The Battle of Megiddo against Canaan city-states was his first campaign. Excel in both government and military, his rule developed the New Kingdom into the world first superpower that no country could rival it.

Name: King of Kadesh
Description: Unnamed King of Kadesh who led the city-states rebellion against the New Kingdom shortly after Pharaoh Thutmose III ascend to the throne. He and the other leaders of nearby Canaanites nation and tribe probably wait for the right moment to start this rebellion since the reign of the previous Pharoah Hatshepsut. Personally led the army in the Plain of Megiddo but lost against the brilliant military mind of Napoleon of Ancient Egypt. He and his allies surrendered after the Siege of Megiddo and sent the sons as a hostage to Egypt.
